block.p: Yun Won Cho was married yesterday to Peter Austin Lyons at the Church of St. Andrew in New York. The Rev. Louis T. Garaventa, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

Ms. Cho, 38, is keeping her name. She is an associate vice president for fund-raising at Rutgers. She graduated cum laude from Yale and received a master's degree in history from the University of California, Los Angeles. She is a daughter of Jong-Wan Cho and Dong-Ik Cho of Basking Ridge, N.J. Her parents retired as the owners of dry-cleaning businesses in Gillette and Warren, N.J.
Yun Won Cho was married yesterday to Peter Austin Lyons at the Church of St. Andrew in New York. The Rev. Louis T. Garaventa, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.
Yun Won Cho was married yesterday to Peter Austin Lyons at the Church of St. Andrew in New York. The Rev. Louis T. Garaventa, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

Ms. Cho, 38, is keeping her name. She is an associate vice president for fund-raising at Rutgers. She graduated cum laude from Yale and received a master's degree in history from the University of California, Los Angeles. She is a daughter of Jong-Wan Cho and Dong-Ik Cho of Basking Ridge, N.J. Her parents retired as the owners of dry-cleaning businesses in Gillette and Warren, N.J.

Mr. Lyons, also 38, is a senior real estate manager at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in New York. He graduated from Trinity College in Hartford. He is a son of Mary Anne Lyons and the late William F. Lyons of New York. His mother is a first-grade teacher at Public School 133 in New York. His father was an executive vice president of Wachovia Securities in New York; he was in charge of American Stock Exchange floor trading and operations.
The couple met almost 20 years ago through a mutual friend.

Although they trained for a marathon together in 1998, they weren't much more than acquaintances until October 2004, when they saw each other at a Halloween party. Their first date, almost a year later, was a walk through Central Park to see ''The Gates,'' the installation by Christo, and then a trip to the Metropolitan Museum. ''I thought by being cultural on the first date, I could get a second date,'' Mr. Lyons said.
Last August, during a training run for a half-marathon in Central Park, Mr. Lyons faked an ankle injury.
As she leaned over to help, Ms. Cho was floored when Mr. Lyons got to one knee and held up an engagement ring.
''I had absolutely no idea it was coming,'' she said. ''Who proposes when you're going on a run?''
